content.description:
Climb up to a stance bellow a very thin crack, make hard moves up past two bolts eventually moving right to a much large crack that will accept your hands. Stellar thin crack climbing. Can be top roped by walking around the left or right sides of the wall.

Just after Cave Man the trail dips down and to the left, the first bolt is immediately visible here.
Two hangars at top. 2 bolts then mixed cams/nuts at the top.

Start in the small cave. Climb straight up to the anchors or traverse out right to the flake for a more exciting finish. Can be top roped by walking around the left or right sides of the wall. As you approach Lower Kitselas there is a little cave with a tree growing directly in front of it. TR can be accessed by walking around to the left of the climb a short ways. Left route: #4 for the bottom crux, then #3, #2 and 0.75. No anchors at top, but a tree you can use for TR. Walk off.

Right route: Two hangars top. A .75, and a #1 or #2 cam will get you through the crack then a piece of small pro is needed at the top to get to the anchor.

An overhanging splitter corner crack. One of the best climbs in the Terrace area of any grade. Can be top-roped by scrambling up the gully on the right by Smeagol.

Start at the bottom of the crack in the large overhung area in the middle of the crag.
Two bolts with chain. Will take .75's and 1's at the bottom and smaller gear as you progress up the climb.

Not much to be said about this one. The tiny fissure in the rock the bolts follow looks to be near un-climbable. Perhaps the route creator could make themselves known. Good luck. Can be top roped by walking around the left or right sides of the wall.

***NOTE TO CLIMBERS***
The rating given here is unreliable as I haven't found anyone whose confirmed the grade.

Immediately to the left of the big cave and just to the right of Afro Samurai one can see the bolts.
Two hangars with rings at top. 5 bolts then cams/nute to finish at the top.

Start on the left side of the wall on a horn in a shallow corner and make a dynamic move up and right to a ledge. Mantle up and pull through the bulges making powerful and balancy moves to a rest. Continue up the wall to a thin crack leading to the top. A top quality route worthy of projecting. Can be top roped by walking around the left or right sides of the wall.

Look to the left of the gully at the end of the wall.
Two hangars with rings at top. 6 bolts. The ground at the top can be unstable due to loose dead foliage so be cautious when approaching anchors. A large block has recently been pried off the wall allowing for a small ledge to stand on to make your anchor.

Start on the right side of the first bolt and lean out from by the tree to clip. An alternate start can be done by starting directly below the bolt to spice things up a little bit. Â A long move leads to good holds on the slanting rails above. Move up through these overlaps to the ledge above to the anchors. Fun, tricky face climbing adding some great steeper sport climbing to the Kitselas area.

Look to the left of the gully, its the last climb with a small tree directly beside it.
Two hangars with rings at top. 5 bolts.

Boulder on good edges and tricky feet through the tough bulge and you'll be rewarded with fun technical face climbing above. Can be top roped by walking around the left or right sides of the wall.

***This climb is fairly new and grade could still be considered up for debate***

Climb starts just right of the anchors for Gollum on the sloping ledge. Belay from the gully you use to approach or there is a hangar on the flat surface you start on to clip in to.
Bolted anchor with rings. Consider putting a locking carabiner on the first bolt for security through the crux. The ground at the top can be unstable due to loose dead foliage so be cautious when approaching anchors.

Something totally different to the rest of the climbs at Kitselas. Scramble into the back of a deep corner, move up left (5.9) through roofs above. Right variation is harder and has no anchor at top. Can be top roped by walking around to the right or left sides of the wall.

Located at the back of a little gully around the corner from Gollum.
Two hangars with rings at top on the left variation and no hangars on the right on. The ground at the top can be unstable due to loose dead foliage so be cautious when approaching anchors. There is a fixed line tied to a nearby tree but its condition is getting questionable and should likely be replaced soon. Consider setting up your own rappel off a nearby strong tree to access the anchors if you really want to top rope it.

Wander on past the first two walls and into a bush a short ways and you'll be find yourself at Lower Kitselas. Home to the terrace classic known as Gollum (5.11a) as well as some other great climbs Very different climbing from the other walls at Kitselas.
